review.title: Joint POS Tagging and Dependency Parsing with Transition-based Neural Networks
review.abstract: While part-of-speech (POS) tagging and dependency parsing are observed to be closely related, existing work on joint modeling with manually crafted feature templates suffers from the feature sparsity and incompleteness problems. In this paper, we propose an approach to joint POS tagging and dependency parsing using transition-based neural networks. Three neural network based classifiers are designed to resolve shift/reduce, tagging, and labeling conflicts. Experiments show that our approach significantly outperforms previous methods for joint POS tagging and dependency parsing across a variety of natural languages.

metadata.title: Joint POS Tagging and Dependency Parsing with Transition-based Neural Networks

sections.heading: 2 Approach
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Problem Statement
sections.text: As shown in Figure 1, in an English sentence "He won the game," the corresponding tag sequence is "PRP VBD DT NN." These tags denote the part of the language of each word: "He" is a personal pronoun, "won" is a verb in the past tense, "the" is a determinator and "game" is a noun. Figure 1 also shows a dependency tree, which is a collection of dependency slurs. In more formal terms, a natural sentence x = x1,. xN, we denote the corresponding POS tag sequence as t = t1,. & ltts, where t-T is a POS and T is a sentence of all possible tags.

sections.heading: 2.4 Training and Parsing
sections.text: Given a number of training examples {< x (k), t (k), d (k) >} Kk = 1, the training goal is to minimize cross entropy loss plus a "2 regularization term." When parsing, we follow Chen and Manning [2014] to perform greedy decoding; the most likely tag sequence and dependency structure corresponds to a sequence of action configuration pairs with the highest probability: {< c-i, a-i >} 4N − 2i = 1, whereas a-i = argmax aP (a-c-i − 1; c-i) (9) and c-i by applying a-i to c-i − 1.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Setup
sections.text: We evaluate our approach on three sets of data: the English Penn Treebank (PTB) with annotated English phrase structure trees, the Chinese Penn Treebank (CTB) version 5.1 with annotated Chinese phrase structure trees, and the Universal Dependency Treebank (UD) version 1.2 4 with annotated dependency trees across a number of natural languages. We use the standard splitting method to divide the PTB records into training, development, and test sections, and convert the phrase structure trees into dependency trees of the Stanford dependency tree v3.3.0 [de Marneffe et al., 2006]. For the CTB5.1 datasets, we follow previous work [Hatori et al., 2011; Bohnet and Nivre, 2012] to divide the datasets into training, development, and test sections, and use the Penn2Malt tool with the header rule of Zhang [and Clark], the structural trees, 2008, and the phratic trees.

sections.heading: 3.2 Main Results
sections.text: Our common model brings significant improvements in both POS labeling (POS) and dependency analysis (LAS) compared to the pipeline model (the p-value is less than 10 − 5 for paired t-tests), and we compare our common model with the base model of POS labeling, which can be treated as an oracle performance of our common model. Although the common model offers improved performance over the pipeline model, it still has a lot of room to accommodate the oracle5We are very grateful to the authors for sharing their data with us.

sections.heading: 3.3 Discussion
sections.text: To investigate the effects of POS tagging on parsing dependencies, we perform an analysis of the CTB5.1 dataset to illustrate the effectiveness of the common model. Here, we examine in detail the benefits of tagging-parsing interaction in our common model. First, we can remove the tag representations from the analysis in Eq. (4) and Eq. (6): h-parse = W-parse [xS2; xS1; xS0; xB0] (10) h-label = W-label [xS1; xS0] (11) Similarly, we can remove the syntactic information from tagging in Eq. (2) to examine the effect of parsing dependencies on POS tagging: h-S0tag = W-tag = W-label (1) tag [xB − 2; tB − 2; xS0; BxC0] is a unique predictor of TB development.

sections.heading: 4 Related Work
sections.text: Our work is closely related to two areas of research: (1) joint POS marking and dependency analysis using feature templates and (2) the analysis of neuronal dependencies.

sections.heading: 4.1 Joint Modeling with Feature Templates
sections.text: Most previous efforts at joint POS marking and dependency analysis have focused on developing linear models with characteristic patterns [Li et al., 2011; Hatori et al., 2011; Bohnet and Nivre, 2012], introducing transition systems that can perform POS marking and dependency analysis in a common search space.Our transition system differs from previous work in separating structural, marking, and labeling actions. This leads to three small classifiers with fewer classes (i.e. | T | classes for the tag classifier, 3 for the layer / reduction classifier, and | L | for the label classifier), rather than one large classifier with many more classes (i.e. | T | + 2 | L |). More importantly, we use continuous representations instead of discrete indicator features to build the classifiers. As suggested by Chen and Manning [2014], xlecalized network indicators are critical to using the complexity of parsing, and we often fail to fully utilize them.

sections.heading: 4.2 Neural POS Tagging and Dependency Parsing
sections.text: Our work is also inspired by recent advances in the application of neural networks to POS tagging [Huang et al., 2015] and dependency parsing [Chen and Manning, 2014; Dyer et al., 2015; Ballesteros et al., 2015; Alberti et al., 2015; Ammar et al., 2016; Kiperwasser and Goldberg, 2016; Andor et al., 2016; Wang and Chang, 2016; Cheng et al., 2016; Dozat and Manning, 2017]. Among them, our work is most similar [Zhang and Weiss, 2016], which suggest stack propagation to integrate a tagging model into a neural parser. They propose a stacked pipeline of models and use POS tags as regulators of learned representations. While Zhang and White [2016] use the hidden layer of the tagger network as input for the parser, we are interested in enabling tagging and parsing so that they can be used in a common search space.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have presented an approach to joint tagging of parts of the language and parsing dependencies using transition-based neural networks. Based on a five-step transition system, we are developing three classifiers to resolve structural, tagging and label conflicts. As our approach allows lexicity and syntax to interact in the joint search process, it improves previous work on joint POS tagging and parsing dependencies across three tree banks in a variety of natural languages. Our code will be published at http: / / github. com / lineryang / joint-parser.

metadata.abstractText: While part-of-speech (POS) tagging and dependency parsing are observed to be closely related, existing work on joint modeling with manually crafted feature templates suffers from the feature sparsity and incompleteness problems. In this paper, we propose an approach to joint POS tagging and dependency parsing using transitionbased neural networks. Three neural network based classifiers are designed to resolve shift/reduce, tagging, and labeling conflicts. Experiments show that our approach significantly outperforms previous methods for joint POS tagging and dependency parsing across a variety of natural languages.
